--- title: "Homework 1" author: "Niharika Pola" description: "The homework-1 on descriptive statistics and probability" date: "10/2/2022" format: html: df-print: paged css: styles.css toc: true code-fold: true code-copy: true code-tools: true categories: - hw1 - desriptive statistics - probability --- ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) library(readxl) library(ggplot2) library(stats) knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE) ``` ::: ## Question 1 ## Reading data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Lc <- read_excel("LungCapData.xls") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error: `path` does not exist: 'LungCapData.xls' ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} Lc ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'Lc' not found ``` ::: ::: The data consists of 725 rows and 6 columns. It determines the lung capacity of the based on their age, height and different characteristics. The main key classification that I can see is if they smoke or not. ## 1a The distribution of LungCap looks as follows: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Lc %>% ggplot(aes(LungCap, ..density..)) + geom_histogram(bins= 25, color = "orange") + geom_density(color = "darkblue") + theme_classic() + labs(title = "Probability distribution of LungCap", x = "Lung Capcity", y = "Probability density") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in ggplot(., aes(LungCap, ..density..)): object 'Lc' not found ``` ::: ::: The histogram and density plots show that it is pretty close to a normal distribution. Most of the observations are close to the mean. ## 1b The distribution of LungCap on basis of gender looks as follows: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Lc %>% ggplot(aes(y = dnorm(LungCap), color = Gender)) + geom_boxplot() + theme_classic() + labs(title = "Probability distribution of LungCap based on gender", y = "Probability density") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in ggplot(., aes(y = dnorm(LungCap), color = Gender)): object 'Lc' not found ``` ::: ::: The box plot shows that the probability density of the male is lesser than the female. ## 1c Comparison of mean lung capacities between smokers and non-smokers: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Mean_smoke <- Lc %>% group_by(Smoke) %>% summarise(mean = mean(LungCap)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in group_by(., Smoke): object 'Lc' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} Mean_smoke ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'Mean_smoke' not found ``` ::: ::: From the above table, we see that the mean lung capacity of those who smoke is greater than those who don't smoke, but it doesn't make sense. It also depends on the biological factors of the person who smoke, so we can't conclude it. ## 1d Relationship between Smoke and Lung capacity on basis of given age categories: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Lc <- mutate(Lc, AgeGrp = case_when(Age <= 13 ~ "less than or equal to 13", Age == 14 | Age == 15 ~ "14 to 15", Age == 16 | Age == 17 ~ "16 to 17", Age >= 18 ~ "greater than or equal to 18")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in mutate(Lc, AgeGrp = case_when(Age <= 13 ~ "less than or equal to 13", : object 'Lc' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} Lc %>% ggplot(aes(y = LungCap, color = Smoke)) + geom_histogram(bins = 25) + facet_wrap(vars(AgeGrp)) + theme_classic() + labs(title = "Relationship of LungCap and Smoke based on age categories", y = "Lung Capacity", x = "Frequency") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in ggplot(., aes(y = LungCap, color = Smoke)): object 'Lc' not found ``` ::: ::: From the above plot, we can derive two important observations: 1. The lung capacity of non smokers is more than smokers. 2. The people who smoke are less in age group of "less than or equal to 13". So as the result as age increases the lung capacity decreases. ## 1e Relationship between Smoke and Lung capacity on basis of age: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Lc %>% ggplot(aes(x = Age, y = LungCap, color = Smoke)) + geom_line() + theme_classic() + facet_wrap(vars(Smoke)) + labs(title = "Relationship of LungCap and Smoke based on age", y = "Lung Capacity", x = "Age") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in ggplot(., aes(x = Age, y = LungCap, color = Smoke)): object 'Lc' not found ``` ::: ::: Form the above data we can compare 1d and 1e and can say the results are pretty similar. Only 10 and above age group smoke. ## 1f Calculating the correlation and covariance between Lung Capacity and Age: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Covariance <- cov(Lc$LungCap, Lc$Age) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in is.data.frame(y): object 'Lc' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} Correlation <- cor(Lc$LungCap, Lc$Age) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in is.data.frame(y): object 'Lc' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} Covariance ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'Covariance' not found ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} Correlation ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'Correlation' not found ``` ::: ::: We can observe from the comparison that the covariance is positive and it indicates that there is a direct relationship between age and lung capacity. And the correlation is also positive, so they move in same direction. We can say from these results that as the age increases, the lung capacity also increases that is they are directly proportional to each other. ## Question 2 ## Reading the table ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Prior_convitions <- c(0:4) Inmate_count <- c(128, 434, 160, 64, 24) Pc <- data_frame(Prior_convitions, Inmate_count) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: `data_frame()` was deprecated in tibble 1.1.0. Please use `tibble()` instead. ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} Pc ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Pc <- mutate(Pc, Probability = Inmate_count/sum(Inmate_count)) Pc ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: ## 2a Probability that a randomly selected inmate has exactly 2 prior convictions: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Pc %>% filter(Prior_convitions == 2) %>% select(Probability) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: ## 2b Probability that a randomly selected inmate has fewer than 2 convictions: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} temp <- Pc %>% filter(Prior_convitions < 2) sum(temp$Probability) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0.6938272 ``` ::: ::: ## 2c Probability that a randomly selected inmate has 2 or fewer prior convictions: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} temp <- Pc %>% filter(Prior_convitions <= 2) sum(temp$Probability) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0.891358 ``` ::: ::: ## 2d Probability that a randomly selected inmate has more than 2 prior convictions: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} temp <- Pc %>% filter(Prior_convitions > 2) sum(temp$Probability) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0.108642 ``` ::: ::: ## 2e Expected value for the number of prior convictions: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Pc <- mutate(Pc, Wm = Prior_convitions*Probability) e <- sum(Pc$Wm) e ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1.28642 ``` ::: ::: ## 2f Variance for the Prior Convictions: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} v <-sum(((Pc$Prior_convitions-e)^2)*Pc$Probability) v ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0.8562353 ``` ::: ::: standard deviation for the Prior Convictions: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} sqrt(v) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0.9253298 ``` ::: ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------
